description: logrotate ‐ rotates, compresses, and mails system logs

global_flags.description: on debug mode, which means that no changes are made to the logs and the logrotate state file is not  updated.   Only  debug messages are printed.

think this  is  necessary.   Sometimes this is useful after adding new entries to a logrotate config file, or if  old  log  files  have been removed by hand, as the new files will be created, and log‐ ging will continue correctly.

logrotate  to  log verbose output into the log_file.  The verbose output logged to that file is the same as  when  running logrotate  with -v switch.  The log file is overwritten on every logrotate execution.
mailing  logs.   This command should accept the following arguments:
not  lock  the  state file, for example if locking is unsup‐ ported or prohibited.

logrotate to use an alternate state file.  This is useful if logrotate is being run as a different user for  various  sets of  log  files.   To prevent parallel execution logrotate by de‐ fault acquires a lock on the state file, if  it  cannot  be  ac‐ quired logrotate will exit with value 3.  The default state file is  /var/lib/logrotate/status.   If  /dev/null  is  given as the state file, then logrotate will not try to  lock  or  write  the state file.
logro‐ tate  process.   This option may cause logrotate to wait indefi‐ nitely.  Use with caution.
